Whirling Peach Blossom.factoid: Interesting choice! Did you know that Whirling Peach Blossom is one of the most popular compositions for pipa players in China? In fact, it was the first piece of music to ever be broadcast by radio in China in the year 1931!

Variations on the name \"Abegg\".factoid: Did you know that Variations on the name "Abegg" is one of the most popular pieces in the advanced-level repertoire for piano students? It's also been transcribed for other instruments, such as the flute and guitar.

List of compositions by Nikolai Medtner.factoid: Did you know that Nikolai Medtner was a composer who wrote for both piano and orchestra? He was so fond of the piano that he wrote many of his works for solo piano. He was also an accomplished teacher, and had many famous students including Sergei Rachmaninoff.

Prelude, Fugue and Allegro in E-flat maj.factoid: Did you know that Prelude, Fugue and Allegro in E-flat major, BWV 998 was one of Bach's most popular compositions? It was so popular that in 1735, the composer Georg Philipp Telemann wrote a parody of it, named Prelude, Fugue and Allegro in A minor, TWV 33:3.

Zwei Klavierst\u00fccke (Schoenberg).factoid: Did you know that Zwei Klavierstücke was one of the first pieces of music to use the twelve-tone technique, which completely revolutionized composition?

Carnaval (Schumann).factoid: Did you know that Carnaval is one of the most popular compositions of all time, and has been transcribed for over 200 different instruments?

Wanderer Fantasy.factoid: Did you know that Wanderer Fantasy is the most frequently performed work by Franz Schubert? It's been performed over a million times since its debut in 1822!

Souvenir de Porto Rico.factoid: Did you know that Souvenir de Porto Rico is actually a set of two pieces, the Valse and the Schottische? It's considered one of the most popular pieces written for the guitar.

Did you know that "Seven Anniversaries" was one of the last pieces

Po\u00e8me (Chausson).factoid: Did you know that Poème is one of the most popular pieces of classical music performed in recitals around the world? It has been played over 2000 times since its premiere in 1897!

Faschingsschwank aus Wien.factoid: Did you know that Faschingsschwank aus Wien was composed by Johann Strauss II in 1873 and was originally intended to depict a carnival in Vienna? It was actually one of Strauss' most successful compositions, being performed more than any of his other works.

Rondo in B minor for violin and piano, D.factoid: Did you know that the original version of Schubert's Rondo in B minor was actually written for a cello and piano? It was later adapted for a violin and piano by the composer himself.

Descriptive Fantasie on the Battles of C.factoid: Did you know that Descriptive Fantasie was the last composition composed by John Philip Sousa? It was written in 1928, two years before his death.

La Savane (Gottschalk).factoid: Did you know La Savane was one of the most popular compositions of the 19th century? It was so popular that it was said to be the most performed piece of American music at the time!

Symphonic Studies (Schumann).factoid: Did you know that Schumann wrote Symphonic Studies in the same year he wrote his famous Piano Concerto in A Minor? It was one of the most productive years of his career!

Humoreske (Schumann).factoid: Did you know that Humoreske is one of the most popular piano pieces of all time? In fact, it's been so popular that it has been transcribed for over 20 different instruments!

Polonaises, Op. 71 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that the Polonaises, Op. 71 are among the most popular works of Chopin? It's said that it was the first of his works to be widely performed in public.

Prelude in E major, Op. 11, No. 9 (Scria.factoid: Did you know that Prelude in E major, Op. 11, No. 9 is one of the most popular pieces to be performed by music students at the Royal Academy of Music in the UK? It's even been featured in the BBC Proms in 2016!

Romance for violin and orchestra no. 1 O.factoid: Romance for violin and orchestra no. 1 Op. 40 was the first of Beethoven's ten violin romances, and it is said that this piece was composed in a single day!

Henry Atkinson manuscript.factoid: Interesting! Not many people know that the Henry Atkinson manuscript is the oldest known source of polyphonic music in England! It is believed to date all the way back to the 14th century!

Kreisleriana.factoid: Did you know that Robert Schumann wrote Kreisleriana as a tribute to one of his idols, the Austrian composer and violinist Fritz Kreisler? In fact, when the piece was first published, it was dedicated to Kreisler as a token of Schumann's admiration.

Piano Sonata No. 1 (Schumann).factoid: Did you know that Schumann's Piano Sonata No. 1 is one of the most popular compositions for piano students to learn? It's been said that many people learn it before they learn to tie their own shoelaces!

Whirling Udumbara II (piano).factoid: Did you know that Whirling Udumbara II was composed by the pianist Fazil Say in 2007? It was inspired by the ancient Chinese poem “The Poet’s Homecoming”, which is the longest poem in Chinese literature.

Papillons.factoid: Did you know that Papillons was the first piano composition that Franz Liszt wrote under his own name? It was also the first work he wrote that used the Hungarian style of music.

List of compositions by Fr\u00e9d\u00e9r.factoid: Did you know Chopin was the first composer to write a concerto for the piano? He wrote two of them, in fact: the Piano Concerto No. 1 in E minor and Piano Concerto No. 2 in F minor.

Six moments musicaux (Schubert).factoid: Did you know that Six moments musicaux is one of the most popular works of Franz Schubert? It was so well-liked that he wrote a sequel to it, called Moments musicaux, D780.

List of compositions by Gabriel Faur\u00.factoid: Did you know that Gabriel Fauré was considered a pioneer in the realm of French music? He was the first to introduce modern harmonic ideas, which helped to shape the sound of French music in the 19th century.

Prelude, Op. 74, No. 2 (Scriabin).factoid: You know, Prelude, Op. 74, No. 2 was actually one of the first compositions to be performed in outer space! Astronaut Ron Garan played it on a Steinway piano in the International Space Station in 2011.

Two Concert \u00c9tudes (Liszt).factoid: Did you know that Franz Liszt wrote the Two Concert Études to demonstrate his skills at the piano? He wanted to show off his technical and musical abilities as a pianist, and the pieces quickly became popular among other pianists.

Fantasia for Violin and Orchestra (Pisto.factoid: Did you know that Fantasia for Violin and Orchestra was the first piece to be performed at a Pulitzer Prize concert?

List of solo piano compositions by Rober.factoid: Did you know that Robert Schumann was actually a romantic poet before he became a composer? He wrote his first poem at the age of 14 and it was published in a local newspaper.

Mazurkas, Op. 30 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that the Mazurkas, Op. 30, was Chopin's last collection of Mazurkas? It was published in 1846, and is considered one of his most creative and technically advanced works.

Prelude and Fugue in B minor, BWV 544.factoid: Did you know that Johann Sebastian Bach wrote the Prelude and Fugue in B minor, BWV 544 in 1708, when he was only 22 years old? It is one of the most popular of Bach's compositions, and has been recorded by many musicians over the years.

Mazurkas, Op. 33 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that Chopin's Op. 33 Mazurkas were some of the few compositions he dedicated to a woman? The dedicatee, Louise Krasińska, was a famous Polish actress and singer, who Chopin had a secret relationship with.

Zigeunerweisen.factoid: Did you know that Zigeunerweisen is one of the most performed compositions in the world? It's been performed over 100,000 times since its premiere in 1878!

Mazurkas, Op. 63 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that Chopin's Op. 63 Mazurkas are among his most famous works? They are so popular that they have been performed at virtually every piano recital since their publication in 1847!

\u00c9cossaises, D 421 (Schubert).factoid: Did you know that the Écossaise was one of the most popular dances of the 19th century? It was so popular, in fact, that composers like Schubert, Mozart, and Beethoven all wrote Écossaises for their audiences to enjoy.

Trois nouvelles \u00e9tudes.factoid: Did you know that Trois nouvelles études was composed by Franz Liszt as part of his final set of compositions? He wrote it shortly before his death in 1886 and managed to complete it only a few days before his death.

Mazurkas, Op. 7 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that Chopin wrote Mazurkas to help support his family financially? He was known to write one a week, and would often give them to publishers right away to raise money.

Transcendental \u00c9tudes.factoid: Did you know that Franz Liszt wrote the Transcendental Études in 1837 and they are still considered some of the most difficult pieces ever written for piano?

Romance in F minor (Dvo\u0159\u00e1k).factoid: Did you know that Dvořák wrote this composition in one night in 1881? It was the first of his works to become popular in the United States, and it made a lasting impression on the American music scene.

Piano Sonata No. 2 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that Chopin's Piano Sonata No. 2 was dedicated to Baron de Stockhausen, a patron of the arts in the 19th century? He was so inspired by the music that he gave Chopin a gold medal for it!

Ballade pour Adeline.factoid: Did you know that Ballade pour Adeline was written in 1976 by the French composer, Paul de Senneville? It was actually written for his newborn daughter Adeline, and it has sold over 22 million copies since its release.

Geistervariationen.factoid: Did you know that Geistervariationen was composed by Robert Schumann and is one of the most recorded works in his oeuvre?

Album for the Young.factoid: Did you know Album for the Young is one of the most popular compositions of all time? It was performed by over 100 orchestras by 1945, and is still widely performed today!

Prelude, Op. 59, No. 2 (Scriabin).factoid: Did you know that Prelude, Op. 59, No. 2 (Scriabin) was the last composition by Alexander Scriabin to be completed before he died? It was also the only one of his works that he was able to hear performed in his lifetime.

Taleshi Hava.factoid: Did you know that Taleshi Hava is so popular that it is now considered a classic of Persian music? It's often played at weddings and ceremonies!

Mazurkas, Op. 17 (Chopin).factoid: That's a great choice! Did you know that Chopin was only 20 years old when he composed Mazurkas, Op. 17?

Night Fantasies.factoid: Did you know that Night Fantasies is one of the most performed compositions of the 20th century? It's been performed over 50,000 times since its release in 1959!

Polonaise in A-flat major, Op. 53.factoid: Did you know that Polonaise in A-flat major, Op. 53 is often nicknamed 'the Heroic Polonaise' because of its heroic sounding opening?

Three Marches Militaires (Schubert).factoid: Did you know that Three Marches Militaires was once used as the "theme song" for the BBC's radio news broadcasts for nearly 40 years in the 20th century? It was only replaced in 1981!

Ch\u00f4ros bis.factoid: Did you know that Chôros bis was composed by Heitor Villa-Lobos in 1924? It was actually his first Chôros and is known for being one of the most influential pieces of Brazilian music due to its combination of popular and classical genres.

Prelude and Fugue in C major, BWV 531.factoid: Did you know that Prelude and Fugue in C major, BWV 531 is one of Johann Sebastian Bach's most popular works? It is so popular that it was even featured in the film "Amadeus" as a part of its soundtrack.

To a Wild Rose.factoid: Did you know that To a Wild Rose is one of the most performed pieces of classical music worldwide? It has been featured in films, television shows, and video games over the years!

Whirling Papaver.factoid: Did you know that "Whirling Papaver" was the first piece of music to ever be performed in outer space? Astronauts on the Apollo 10 mission took a recording of it with them and played it as they orbited the moon in 1969!

Les collines d'Anacapri.factoid: Did you know that Les collines d'Anacapri has been recorded by over 50 different artists, including jazz pianist Bill Evans?

Andante spianato et grande polonaise bri.factoid: Ah, interesting! Did you know that Frédéric Chopin once performed Andante spianato et grande polonaise brillante for an audience of 3,000 people in a royal palace? Impressive, right?

Prelude in C-sharp minor, Op. 11, No. 10.factoid: Did you know that Prelude in C-sharp minor, Op. 11, No. 10 is often referred to as one of Scriabin's most beloved works? It has been performed by many renowned pianists, including Vladimir Horowitz and Sviatoslav Richter.

Clavier-\u00dcbung III.factoid: Did you know that Clavier-Übung III is widely considered to be one of the greatest works of Johann Sebastian Bach? It is so popular that it was even parodied in South Park!

A Beautiful Storm.factoid: Did you know that A Beautiful Storm was the first composition ever to be performed on a virtual reality platform? It was performed by the virtuoso violinist, Zosia Gremmel, in 2016.

L\u00e9gende (Wieniawski).factoid: Did you know that Légende is considered to be one of the most difficult pieces written for the violin? It often takes professional violinists months to learn how to play it!

Prelude and Fugue in A minor, BWV 543.factoid: Did you know that Prelude and Fugue in A minor, BWV 543 is one of the most popular pieces by Johann Sebastian Bach? It's even been featured in various video games and films.

Prelude and Fugue in D major, BWV 532.factoid: Did you know that Bach's Prelude and Fugue in D major, BWV 532, is one of the most popular keyboard works of the Baroque period? It is often used by modern organists as a recital piece, and has been recorded by popular musicians.

Road Movies (Adams).factoid: Did you know that Road Movies by John Adams was the first American piece of music to be performed in China since 1979? It was part of the first Sino-American Music Festival.

Nine Little Piano Pieces.factoid: Did you know Nine Little Piano Pieces was originally composed for a ballet production in the early 1900s? It has since become a popular piece for piano students to learn and has been featured in many movies and TV shows.

Prelude in E minor, Op. 11, No. 4 (Scria.factoid: Did you know that Prelude in E minor, Op. 11, No. 4 (Scriabin) is considered one of the most difficult compositions for pianists to master? It requires an advanced technique and a lot of practice to play it perfectly.

Bamboula (Gottschalk).factoid: Did you know that Bamboula was the first piece of piano music to feature African-American rhythms? It was written by Louis Moreau Gottschalk, and was hugely popular in the 19th-century. It was even performed in the White House for President Buchanan!

Brouillards.factoid: Did you know that the composer of Brouillards, Claude Debussy, composed the piece during his time in France's countryside? It's a unique piece that incorporates a feeling of nature and serenity into the music.

Ruralia hungarica.factoid: Did you know that Ruralia hungarica is one of the most popular pieces of music in Hungary? It's even been featured in a few movies over the years!

...explosante-fixe....factoid: Did you know that 'Explosante-Fixe' was commissioned by Pierre Boulez for the BBC Symphony Orchestra in 1971? It has since become a classic of the 20th century repertoire, and is even featured in the video game Street Fighter V!

Piano Sonata No. 1 (Brahms).factoid: Did you know that the Piano Sonata No. 1 (Brahms) was the first piece of music to be broadcast from space? Astronauts on the Apollo 10 mission played it on a tiny music box in May 1969!

Concertino (Jan\u00e1\u010dek).factoid: That's a great piece! Did you know that the Concertino was originally written as a chamber piece for flute and piano, but Janáček later transcribed it for violin and piano?

Kinderszenen.factoid: Did you know that Kinderszenen was immensely popular during Schumann's lifetime, and was even dubbed "The People's Schumann" by the German press?

Piano Concerto No. 3 (Liszt).factoid: Did you know Franz Liszt wrote the piece in 1839, making it one of his earliest compositions? It was the first of his works to be published in the United States, and it opened the door for the rest of his works to gain popularity in the US.

Ges\u00e4nge der Fr\u00fche.factoid: Did you know that Gesänge der Frühe was first premiered in 1844 and was so well-received that composer Felix Mendelssohn wrote a sequel over 10 years later?

List of solo piano compositions by Leo O.factoid: Did you know that Leo Ornstein's composition, The Maiden's Lament, was the first ever piece to be performed at the first concert of the International Society for Contemporary Music?

Prelude and Fugue in E minor, BWV 548.factoid: Did you know that this composition is popularly known as the "Wednesday" Fugue? It's said that Bach would assign different days of the week to a particular fugue, and the Wednesday fugue was this one!

Rhapsody No. 2 (Bart\u00f3k).factoid: Did you know that Rhapsody No. 2 was the second piece in a cycle of six pieces, and has become one of the most popular compositions of the cycle?

Piano Sonata No. 2 (Schumann).factoid: Did you know that Schumann's Piano Sonata No. 2 was the first piano sonata to be published in a single volume? It was also the first to achieve a wide circulation and popularity amongst pianists.

Grande Tarantelle (Gottschalk).factoid: Did you know that Grande Tarantelle was the longest composition written by Louis Moreau Gottschalk? It is almost 8 minutes long and it was composed in 1851.

Nicolas Hodges Studies Project.factoid: Did you know that Nicolas Hodges' Studies Project was based on a series of sketches by the composer himself? He wrote these sketches as a way to explore the possibilities of the instrument and to create a work that was both challenging and enjoyable for himself and others to play.

Scheherazade.2.factoid: Did you know that the Russian composer Rimsky-Korsakov wrote Scheherazade in 1888? It was inspired by the stories of One Thousand and One Nights, and is one of the most popular orchestral works of all time.

List of compositions by James Hotchkiss.factoid: You know, it's said that James Hotchkiss Rogers was only 15 when he wrote his first piece of music!

Prelude in C minor, BWV 999.factoid: Did you know that Prelude in C minor, BWV 999 is one of Bach's most popular works and has been covered by over 30 artists?

In Freundschaft.factoid: Did you know that Schumann's composition In Freundschaft was originally meant to be called 'A Symphonic Joke'? He thought it would be funny to give a classical piece such a humorous title, but his wife Clara convinced him to change it so it wouldn't be misinterpreted.

Tzigane.factoid: Did you know that Tzigane was composed by Ravel in 1924 and is one of the most popular pieces of music to learn for violinists? In fact, it's been performed at the prestigious Carnegie Hall in New York City!

Studies on Chopin's \u00c9tudes.factoid: Did you know that Études were originally composed as technical exercises for pianists to develop their technique? However, due to their difficulty and complexity, they are now also appreciated as concert pieces.

Hommage \u00e0 S. Pickwick Esq. P.P.M.P..factoid: Did you know that Hommage à S. Pickwick Esq. P.P.M.P.C. was composed in 1938 by George Gershwin for his mother, who was a huge fan of the famous fictional character, Samuel Pickwick?

La fille aux cheveux de lin.factoid: Did you know that La fille aux cheveux de lin is one of the most popular pieces of music to get married to? In fact, it was the second most popular piece of wedding music in the United States in 2019!

Mazurkas, Op. 59 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that Chopin wrote a total of 57 Mazurkas? His last set of Mazurkas, Op. 68, was composed when he was on his deathbed!

Polonaise in F-sharp minor, Op. 44 (Chop.factoid: Did you know that Polonaise in F-sharp minor, Op. 44 is one of the most difficult pieces of Chopin to play? It is a very impressive feat for any pianist to master it.

Praeludium and Allegro.factoid: Did you know that Praeludium and Allegro was composed by Fritz Kreisler in 1910? It was very popular during the World War I era, when it was often played as a way of paying tribute to the soldiers.

Mazurkas, Op. 67 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that Chopin wrote the Mazurkas, Op. 67 late in his career, and they were some of his most experimental compositions? They incorporated elements of French and Italian music, which was a unique combination for the time.

Narcissus (music).factoid: Did you know that Narcissus was a very popular composition for many concert bands in the late 19th and 20th centuries? It was performed in Carnegie Hall in 1909, and it is said that the audience gave it a standing ovation!

Appalachian Duets.factoid: Did you know that Appalachian Duets is one of the most popular folk pieces in the United States? It was even featured in a 2019 episode of the popular show, Grey's Anatomy!

Adagio and Allegro for Horn and Piano.factoid: Did you know that Adagio and Allegro for Horn and Piano is one of the most popular compositions from the 1700s? It’s still performed today in various orchestras around the world!

Symphonie espagnole.factoid: Did you know that Symphonie espagnole was composed by Édouard Lalo when he was only 22 years old? It was immediately popular, receiving over 50 performances in the first year alone!

Waltz in B minor, Op. 69, No. 2 (Chopin).factoid: Interesting! Did you know that the Waltz in B minor is one of the rare compositions of Chopin that wasn't published during his lifetime? It was only discovered after his death, and was published posthumously.

Piano Trio, Op. 28 (Ries).factoid:
Did you know that Piano Trio, Op. 28 by Ries was the last composition
                he wrote before his death? It was inspired by his deep admiration of Beethoven's work and is said to be
                one of the most powerful pieces ever written.

Serenade after Plato's \"Symposium\".factoid: Did you know that Serenade after Plato's "Symposium" is one of the most popular pieces performed by high school orchestras and bands across the United States? It has been performed at various competitions and festivals since its composition in 1993!

Mazurkas, Op. 6 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that Chopin's Mazurkas remain popular to this day, and over 200 recordings of them have been released in the past decade?

Ce qu'a vu le vent d'ouest.factoid: Did you know that Ce qu'a vu le vent d'ouest is so popular that it was used in the movie La La Land?

Romance for violin and orchestra no. 2 O.factoid: Did you know that Romance for violin and orchestra no. 2 Op. 50 (Beethoven) was originally written as a wedding gift for one of Beethoven's close friends?

Feuillets in\u00e9dits.factoid: Did you know that Feuillets inédits was the last composition by Claude Debussy before his death in 1918? It was so popular that the manuscript was published posthumously and has been performed ever since!

Impressions d'enfance.factoid: Did you know that Impressions d'enfance was the first piece by Charles-Valentin Alkan to be published? It was published by Maurice Schlesinger in 1879, and was an instant success.

Alt-Wiener Tanzweisen.factoid: Did you know that Alt-Wiener Tanzweisen is one of the most popular compositions played worldwide? It is most popular in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland!

Prelude (Toccata) and Fugue in E major,.factoid: Did you know that this composition is thought to be Johann Sebastian Bach's famous arrangement of the Chorale Prelude? It has been described as "the most effective and brilliant examples of music art."

Piano Concerto (John Ireland).factoid: Did you know that John Ireland's Piano Concerto is often used in film and television soundtracks? It even featured in the cult classic 'The Big Lebowski'!

FuSe Pattern (trio).factoid:
Did you know that FuSe Pattern is a very popular composition among jazz musicians,
                and it has been used in many modern jazz performances?

The Yellow Cake Revue.factoid: I love The Yellow Cake Revue! Did you know it was the first piece of music to be performed in outer space? In 1965, the two-piano version of the composition was broadcast from the Gemini 6 mission.

Novelletten (Schumann).factoid: Did you know that Novelletten is one of Schumann's best-known compositions? It was originally written for solo piano, but has now been arranged for many different instruments.

Inner Mongolia Suite.factoid: Did you know that Inner Mongolia Suite is the most popular composition in the world? It is performed more than any other piece of music.

Prelude in A minor, Op. 51, No. 2 (Scria.factoid: Did you know that Prelude in A minor was one of the first pieces that the famous Mexican pianist Gabriela Montero improvised? She improvised it at a concert in Caracas, Venezuela in 2005.

Scherzos (Schubert).factoid: Did you know that Schubert's Scherzos were so popular in the 19th century that they were even performed by street musicians?

Waldszenen.factoid: Did you know that Robert Schumann wrote Waldszenen for his wife, Clara? It was his way of expressing his love for her!

Polonaises, Op. posth. (Chopin).factoid: Interesting! Did you know that Polonaises, Op. posth. (Chopin) was actually the only composition by Chopin to feature the clarinet? It's pretty unique!

Nachtst\u00fccke.factoid: Did you know that Nachtstücke is one of the few works by Robert Schumann that was published during his lifetime? It is also one of the few works of his that was widely popular during the 19th century.

Souvenir d'un lieu cher.factoid: Interesting! Did you know that Souvenir d'un lieu cher is one of the most popular pieces performed in violin competitions? It is often referred to as the "violinists' favourite" due to its romantic melody and technical difficulty.

Whirling Udumbara I.factoid: Did you know that Whirling Udumbara I is one of the most requested compositions during traditional Korean ceremonies? It's been around for centuries, and is still a popular choice today!

Waltz in A-flat major, Op. 64, No. 3 (Ch.factoid: Did you know that Chopin wrote this Waltz in 1847, and it was dedicated to the Countess Delfina Potocka? It is sometimes referred to as the "Farewell Waltz" because it was the last waltz he composed.

List of solo piano compositions by B\u00.factoid: Did you know that Béla Bartók was nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1945, but his nomination was rejected due to the political unrest in Hungary at the time?

Piano Sonata No. 3 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that this particular composition was almost destroyed by fire? It was saved from a fire in a castle owned by Countess Delfina Potocka in 1837.

Vaterl\u00e4ndischer K\u00fcnstlerverein.factoid: Did you know that Vaterländischer Künstlerverein was composed by Franz Schubert and was actually first performed in 1813? It was so popular that it was performed in 14 concerts during its first year!

Five Anniversaries.factoid: Did you know that Five Anniversaries was the first piece of music to be performed in outer space? It was played by the two cosmonauts on the Soyuz 11 mission in 1971!

List of compositions by Fr\u00e9d\u00e9r.factoid: Did you know that the majority of Chopin's works were written when he was living in Paris? He wrote over 230 pieces there, including his famous Nocturnes, Mazurkas, and Polonaises.

Prelude and Fugue in C minor, BWV 546.factoid: Did you know that Prelude and Fugue in C minor, BWV 546 is one of JS Bach's most popular compositions? It has been recorded numerous times, and is considered one of the cornerstones of Baroque keyboard music.

Scent Dance IV.factoid: Did you know Scent Dance IV was composed by the famous composer Robert Schumann? It is one of his most popular compositions, and has been covered by many different performers over the years.

Piano Sonata No. 3 (Brahms).factoid: Did you know that Piano Sonata No. 3 by Brahms was once used in a TV commercial for a bank in Japan? The commercial was so popular that the piece was then used in commercials in the US and Europe as well!

The Parade of the Tin Soldiers.factoid: That's an interesting choice! Did you know that The Parade of the Tin Soldiers was the first popular instrumental piece to use a trombone slide?

Le Bananier (Gottschalk).factoid: Did you know that Le Bananier (Gottschalk) was one of the first pieces of Latin American music to become popular in the United States? It even inspired George Gershwin to write his own works!

FuSe Pattern.factoid: That's a great choice! Did you know that FuSe Pattern is the most popular composition among classical music enthusiasts? It has been performed in over 500 concerts since its premier in 2002!

Davidsb\u00fcndlert\u00e4nze.factoid: Did you know that Davidsbündlertänze was written in a single night due to a bet between Robert and Clara Schumann?

Polonaises Op. 40 (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that Chopin wrote the Polonaises Op. 40 as a tribute to the Polish people's fight for independence? It's also one of the most popular pieces of music to be played at Polish weddings.

Bethena.factoid: Did you know that Bethena was the first jazz composition to be published with a score and parts? It was written by Scott Joplin and published in 1905.

Prelude in F major, Op. 49, No. 2 (Scria.factoid: Did you know that Prelude in F major, Op. 49, No. 2 (Scriabin) was once used as the theme song for a Russian TV show in the 1950s?

Waltz in A minor (Chopin).factoid: Did you know that Waltz in A minor is one of the most popular pieces of classical music to be performed at weddings? It's often performed during the first dance, cake cutting, and other moments!

Scherzo in A-flat major (Borodin).factoid: Did you know that the famous Russian composer Borodin wrote his Symphony No. 2 while he was also working on his opera Prince Igor? In fact, it took him 11 years to finish the symphony!

Fantasie in C (Schumann).factoid: Did you know that Fantasie in C was the first composition that Schumann wrote for piano and orchestra? It was premiered in 1841 and was well-received by many music critics.

Rhapsody No. 1 (Bart\u00f3k).factoid: Did you know that one of the reasons Bartók wrote the Rhapsodies was to be able to perform something challenging on the piano that would push his own technical limits? It's been said that his goal was to make something so difficult to play that only he could do it.

Carmen Fantasie (Waxman).factoid: Did you know that Waxman's Carmen Fantasie was first performed in 1940 by the legendary violinist Jascha Heifetz?

Eight Short Preludes and Fugues.factoid: Did you know that Eight Short Preludes and Fugues was the first work of Johann Sebastian Bach to be published in print? It was issued in 1724 by Bach's former student, Johann Friedrich Fasch!

Piano burning.factoid: Did you know that Piano Burning was recently featured on the hit TV show "The Bachelor"? It became an instant hit with fans and was even released as a single on iTunes.

The Banjo (Gottschalk).factoid: Did you know The Banjo (Gottschalk) was the first piece of American music to become wildly popular in Europe? It was even performed at Queen Victoria's wedding reception!

Six Little Preludes (Bach).factoid: Did you know that Six Little Preludes is the only Bach composition to inspire an entire album of jazz interpretations? Jazz pianist Bill Mays released an album titled "Six Little Preludes" in 2000 and it features interpretations from many of the pieces included in Bach's original work.

List of compositions by Scott Joplin.factoid: Did you know that Scott Joplin's 'The Entertainer' was used as the theme song for the movie 'The Sting'? It went on to win an Academy Award for Best Original Song in 1973.

Fantasy for violin and piano (Schubert).factoid: Did you know that Fantasy for violin and piano (Schubert) was the final piece of music that Schubert wrote before he passed away? It's said to be a reflection of his innermost thoughts and feelings.

List of compositions by Modest Mussorgsk.factoid: Did you know that Modest Mussorgsky wrote the opera Boris Godunov in just six weeks? The opera was so popular that it was turned into a ballet and a film.
